questions.text: A Child presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
Option A-The case given here is Hand foot and mouth disease. Causative agent is Coxsackievirus A16 virus and enterovirus 71.

Option B- Pox virus causes molluscum contagiosum, presents with asymptomatic papules with central umbilication.

Option C- Herpes virus manifests as

  • Herpes labialis
  • Herpetic gingivostomatitis
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Encephalitis
  • Eczema herpeticum

Choice D- HPV virus manifest as warts

Tag: Hand foot mouth disease

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number: 25.5

questions.text: Which of the histopathological finding is not seen in lichen planus?
questions.solution:
Histopathological findings of Lichen planus:

  • Mild hyperkeratosis
  • Irregular acanthosis
  • Focal wedge shaped hypergranulosis (Responsible for Wickham's striae)→Choice D
  • Basal cell degeneration. Sometimes lead to clefts in dermoepidermal junction called Max joseph spaces
  • Saw tooth rete ridges
  • Colloid bodies/ civatte/apoptotic bodies in lower epidermis and upper dermis→Choice C
  • Dense band like mononuclear infiltration at dermoepidermal junction
  • Interface dermatitis→Choice B
  • Pigment incontinence, presence of melanophages

Camel foot rete ridges- As a result, to accommodate the increasing population of basal cells, rete pegs take a plunge in the dermis in the form of regular elongation of rete ridges, giving the "camel foot" appearance to dermal rete ridges

Seen in Psoriasis vulgaris. (Choice A)

Tag: Lichen planus

Reference: Fundamentals of pathology of skin, 4th edition, Page number:74

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient is a known case of leprosy with multiple, bilaterally symmetrical Plaques and nodules over face, ears, trunk. Glove & stocking anesthesia is present. Which of the following is not treatment of lepra reaction seen in this given type of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Based on given clinical presentation, diagnosis is lepromatous leprosy with Type 2 Lepra reaction.

  • Cessation of anti leprosy treatment is not the treament of type 2 lepra reaction. Antileprosy treatment should be continued.

Option A- Clofazimine

For Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/ orchitis) Clofazimine is used.

Option B- Thalidomide

Thalidomide is of no value in Type I reaction. It is used in management of type II reaction. It is teratogenic hence contraindicated in women.

Option C- Corticosteroids

For Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/orchitis) Corticosteroid is used.

Treatment of lepra type 2 reaction: Continue the antileprosy treatment.

Mild/ moderate (fever with few skin lesions):

  • Rest
  • Chloroquine
  • Aspirin
  • Antimonials (when associated with bone and joint problem)

Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/ orchitis):

  • Steroid
  • Clofazimine (in large doses)
  • Thalidomide

Thalidomide is of no value in Type I reaction It is used in management of type II reaction

It is teratogenic hence contraindicated in women

Tag: Lepra reaction

Reference: IAL Textbook Of Leprosy By Bhushan Kumar, 2nd edition, page number:469

questions.text: Koebner's phenomenon is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Tag: Signs in dermatology

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, page number:123.2

choices.text: Granuloma formation with well-formed epithelioid cells
Large, foamy macrophages with abundant acid-fast bacilli
Dense lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermal-epidermal junction

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with multiple skin lesions characterized by diffuse, nodular, and anesthetic skin changes. The patient also has deformities of the hands and feet. The clinical picture is consistent with lepromatous leprosy. Which of the following is a key histopathological feature of lepromatous leprosy?
questions.solution:
Large, foamy macrophages (also known as lepra cells) with abundant acid-fast bacilli visible on special stains (e.g., Ziehl-Neelsen stain).

(Option B)

This form of leprosy shows widespread dissemination of the bacteria and a paucity of cell-mediated immune response.

Option A: Granuloma formation with well-formed epithelioid cells is more characteristic of tuberculoid leprosy or other granulomatous conditions

Option C: Dense lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermal-epidermal junction is typical of lichen planus rather than leprosy.

Option D: Necrotizing vasculitis with fibrin deposition is seen in conditions like systemic vasculitis rather than leprosy.

Tag: Histopathology of Leprosy

Reference: Fundamentals of pathology of skin, 4th edition, Page number:146

questions.text: A 8 year old child presents with a generalized vesicular eruption all over the body involving the trunk. His brother also had similar rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Varicella:

Morphology: Crops of papules with erythematous halo; rapidly become vesicular (dew drops on rose petal appearance), then pustular.

Eruption at different stages present. Adults usually have a more severe eruption.

Site: Centripetal distribution.

Prophylaxis: Live attenuated vaccine.

Treatment: Specific antiviral therapy (acyclovir 800mg, five times daily × 7-10 days) in adults and in immunocompromised individuals. None needed in children.

Option B- Rubella is a viral disease characterized by rash, swollen glands and fever.

Mucosal involvement results in the Forchheimer sign, in which pinpoint or larger petechiae are noted on the soft palate and uvula during the prodromal period of rubella.

Rash begins on the face that spreads to the neck, trunk and extremities. Appear as erythematous papules about 2-3 mm in size.

Option C- Measles

Presents as fever, malaise, and loss of appetite, followed by conjunctivitis, cough, and coryza. In Prodromal phase, Koplik spots appear.

These are blue-white spots on the inside of the mouth opposite the molars. Erythematous macules ranging from 0.1-1.0cm in diameter appear on the 4th or 5th day following the start of symptoms.

This non-itchy rash begins on the face and behind the ears. Within 24-36 hours it spreads over the entire trunk and extremities (palms and soles rarely involved).

Option D- Mumps

Infection typically presents with a prodrome of headache, fever, fatigue, anorexia, malaise followed by the classic hallmark of the disease, parotitis.

Tag: Chickenpox

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:25.15

questions.text: A patient has a history of thorn prick while working in the garden, the lesion spread linearly up till shoulder. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)

  • Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii
  • It is diamorphic fungus
  • There are 3 types:
  • KOH mount: Cigar shaped yeast
  • Histopathology shows "Asteroid bodies"

Option A- Skin abscesses are collections of pus in the dermis and adipose tissue that usually result from infection.

Option B- A furuncle (or boil) is an acute, usually necrotic, infection of a hair follicle with S. aureus

Option C- Lymphedema is a chronic disease marked by the increased collection of lymphatic fluid in the body, causing swelling.

Tag: Sporotrichosis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:32.71

questions.text: A 40 year old patient with chronic plaque psoriasis with 50% BSA involvement. He has no systemic features and no arthritis. Which of the following should not be used in the management?
questions.solution:
Psoriasis management-

Topical therapy: (<10%)

  • Topical steroids
  • Vitamin D3 analogues
  • Coal tar
  • Anthralin
  • Salicylic acid

Systemic therapy (>10%)

  • Methotrexate→(Choice D)
  • Acitretin
  • Cyclosporine→(Choice C)

Biologics

  • Anti TNF (Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab, Certolizumab pegol)
  • Anti IL-17 ( Secukinumab, Ixekizumab, Brodalumab)
  • Anti IL12/23 p40 (Ustekinumab)
  • IL-23 (Guselkumab, Risankizumab)

Steroids are not given in psoriasis.

Exception: Steroids are DOC for impetigo herpetiformis

Phototherapy(>10%)--------(Choice A)

  • Phototherapy of choice- NBUVB (Narrow band UVB) 311mm
  • PUVA (Psoralen+ UVA)
  • PUVA

Tag: Psoriasis vulgaris

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, page number:25.23

questions.text: What nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic, eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of the hands?
questions.solution:
Pellagra is a systemic disease caused by vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It is characterised by the 4 D's - dermatitis, diarrhoea, dementia and, if untreated, death.

Dermatitis over photoexposed site of body. eczematous lesions over neck also known as 'casal's necklace'. (Choice B)

Pellagra is a disease of a maize and jowar-eating population.Amino-acid imbalance caused by an excess of leucine is the cause of pellagra in both jowar and maize eaters.

Excess of leucine appears to interfere in the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

Etiology:

  • Malabsorption syndromes (jejunoileitis, gastroenterostomy, subtotal gastrectomy, Crohn's disease),
  • Chronic alcoholism,
  • Metabolic derangements (Hartnup disease, carcinoid syndrome), and
  • Drugs (INH, 6-mercaptopurine, 5-fluorouracil, pyrazinamide, phenytoin, chloramphenicol, azathioprine, phenobarbitone, ethionamide)

Option A- Vit B1 deficiency leads to Beriberi

Option C- Vit D deficiency lead to rickets, osteomalacia

Option D- Vit C deficiency leads to scurvy

Tag: Pellagra

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 63.17

questions.text: A 23 year old male patient presented with around 10- 15 Bilateral asymmetrical erythematous infiltrated plaques as shown in the image. Patient was resident of madhya pradesh. Lesions are of varied size and bizarre shapes with irregular borders. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• H/O 10-20 B/L asymmetrical erythematous infiltrated plaques, so its not TT/LL. It should be borderline.
  • The lesion is punched out and margins are raised & scalloping outwards with centre depressed (Inverted saucer shape).
  • The outer border is irregular and has geographic appearance.
  • The above image shows inverted saucer shape lesion, Punched out swiss cheese appearance Suggestive of BB leprosy.

Tag: BB leprosy

Reference: IAL Textbook Of Leprosy By Bhushan Kumar, 2nd edition, page number-238.

questions.text: What will be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows grade 4 acne:

Isotretinoin is the most efficacious treatment for severe acne(grade 4).

Isotretinoin is the only therapy that impacts on all of the major aetiological factors implicated in acne.

It results in a significant reduction in sebum production, influences comedogenesis, lowers surface and ductal P. acnes and has anti-inflammatory properties.

A dose of 0.5-1.0 mg/kg/day dramatically reduces acne.

Key Takeaway:

Acne grade 4- Nodulocystic acne is treated with Oral isotretinoin. It causes side effects like Chelitis, raised LFT and Teratogenicity.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 90.38

questions.text: Match the following therapeutics used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects
questions.solution:
Methotrexate: Hepatotoxic, Bone marrow suppression, Nausea

Cyclosporine: Nephrotoxic, Hypertension

Acitretin: Dyslipidemia, Liver dysfunction, cheilitis, teratogenic

PUVA: Phototoxic erythema(Acute), Long term exposure increases risk for non-melanoma skin cancer

Key Takeaway :

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 35.22

questions.text: A patient was prescribed 50 mg daily acitretin for psoriasis. Which of the following is requires monitoring?
questions.solution:
• Acitretin belongs to a group of drugs known as retinoids. Retinoids include natural and synthetic compounds that have similar activity to vitamin A.
  • Vitamin A helps regulate the immune system, impacts cellular growth, differentiation, and proliferation, and plays a role in embryonic development
  • Acitretin is the only systemic retinoid that is FDA-approved for psoriasis and effective as monotherapy.
  • In psoriasis treatment with acitretin, improvement is seen approximately at weeks 4 to 6. Treatment dosing is initiated at 25-50 mg orally once daily.
  • The use of acitretin is contraindicated in patients with severe hepatic impairment.
  • It is considered a pregnancy category X medicine. As per the box warning, acitretin must not be given to pregnant patients, patients who intend to become pregnant during therapy, or at least three years following discontinuation of treatment. Significant human fetal abnormalities have been reported with the administration of acitretin.
  • Laboratory Abnormality: Hypercholesterolemia, increased liver enzymes, increased creatinine phosphokinase, hepatotoxicity, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, reticulocytosis

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 35, page 28

questions.text: A 28 year old male patient presented with genital ulcer since 1 week. On examination, there was painless, single, well defined indurated ulcer as shown in the image. There was painless inguinal lymph node enlargement. There was a history of unprotected intercourse one month back. What will be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic primary syphilis presentation is a solitary non-tender genital chancre in response to invasion by the T. pallidum.

The ulcer is well defined indurated hard (button like) chancre with shotty painless lymphadenopathy.

Incubation period- 9-90 days

Option A : Herpes progenitalis

Herpes genitalis is among the most common sexually transmitted infections. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2

Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain. It can lead to recurrent lesions.

Treatment with tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

Option B : Chancroid

Chancroid is caused by the gram-negative bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi (H. ducreyi). It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful swollen lymph glands in the inguinal area (bubo). A Gram stain shows 'school of fish appearance'.

Option D : Lymphogranuloma venereum is an ulcerative sexually transmitted infection of the genital area caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1, L2, and L3

lymphogranuloma venereum has three stages of infection :

  • Primary stage characterized by the development of painless genital ulcer or papules.
  • Secondary stage with the development of unilateral or bilateral tender inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy (also called buboes).
  • Late stage with strictures, fibrosis, and fistulae of the anogenital area.

Key Takeaway :

Primary Syphilis Ulcer

  • Single
  • Indurated
  • Non Tender & Non Bleeding
  • Painless Lymphadenopathy

Reference: Sexually Transmitted Diseases And HIV/AIDS By Vinod K. Sharma,2nd edition, Page number:410
